ce:sections.ce:para: In their captivating review, Pereira et al. have provided an overview on the state-of-the-art methods on non-invasive methods of stimulating the brain [1]. Interestingly, the authors have explored the application of microwaves for deep stimulation of the brain. It is very evident that the neurogenerative disorders such as Alzheimer, Parkinson's etc. [2]. will be benefitted if the research gaps on microwave-based brain stimulation are filled. Another attractive feature of this review article is that the authors have concentrated mostly on the deep brain stimulation concept which is the most challenging task. Currently, most of the practical approaches are based only on invasive methods which are prone to several infections for the humans. Hence, the brain stimulation fraternity is always on the lookout for alternatives to solve this problem.

The non-invasive mode of deep brain stimulation is one of the best alternatives for the medical society. However, there are plenty of difficult questions when it comes to practical implementation. These questions make the traditional non-invasive methods practically impossible. It is a common idea that a solution always exists for all the problems. To validate this statement, computer and engineering technology join together to assist the non-invasive mode of deep brain stimulation. One such method is Microwave Brain Stimulation (MBS) which has gained significant attention in the current scenario [3]. The review article has clearly highlighted the different pros of this method which can add a different dimension to the deep brain stimulation. In the microwave-based approach, special attention is given to the antenna which is responsible for focussing the signals on the region of interest inside the brain.

The different aspects of the antenna design are discussed in detail in this review article. Details on the impact of the microwave signals on different types of tissues such as fats, bones, etc. are also given in the review article. These details are necessary since the absorption threshold level of different tissues is different. Special attention is also given to the different parameters of the antenna such as gain, directivity, etc. which indicates the in-depth information available in the review article. The geometric arrangement of the antenna is very important in directing the beams on the region of the interest. Sufficient information on the shapes, radiation patterns, the signal parameters are given which will help the reader to design a practical set-up for deep brain stimulation [4]. The illustrations given in Figure 5 in the review paper are enthralling which will increase the appetite of the reader to begin practical implementations on microwave brain stimulation. Apart from appreciating the earlier research works, the review article is also critical in pin-pointing the lapses in the previous works. Elaborative tables giving the level of analysis by other research works demand special appreciation. The safety aspects from the perception of the clinician, biomedical engineer and the patient is also discussed in detail. The ethical issues are also addressed which is extremely important for any real-time medical experiments. The limitations in terms of the cost involved is also addressed. This will motivate engineers and clinicians to join together in developing novel cost-effective methods for practical applications. One another factor is the inclusion of discussion on optimization methods which is very important from the design perspective.

However, few more comments are in my mind which would add value to the existing review article. What about the materials used for the antenna fabrication? With the numerous choices available, which one is more preferable for such applications? Another comment is on the frequency of the microwave signal to be used for stimulation. Is there any relation between the specific frequency of the signal and the intensity of the stimulation required? Some patients may be suffering from mild neurogenerative disease and few other patients may fall under severe category. How to determine the dosage of input in each case? Also, the microwave frequency is a high frequency signal. What is the guarantee that it will not affect the normal tissues? How do you analyse the success rate between the implantable methods and the microwave-based methods? With several implantable methods available in the literature, how do you foresee the performance of the microwave-based method?

Are there any precautionary measures available to tackle the possible Electro-Magnetic Interference (EMI) [5] with the proposed microwave-based approach? What are the methods available to remove the noisy signals entering the region of interest? What should be the ideal distance between the region of interest and the location of the antenna to avoid the noisy signals? How can the Artificial Intelligence (AI) based approaches be incorporated in the proposed microwave based deep brain stimulation? Are there any specific requirements for the hardware set-up other than the antenna in the overall system? Apart from curing the neurological disorders, are there any other applications associated with the microwave-based deep brain stimulation? On the whole, this review article triggers the interest of the readers to dig deep for novel solutions apart from highlighting the pros and cons of the different primary and secondary concepts associated with microwave-based deep brain stimulation.
